Description.val:
DESCRIPTION: This line item funds modifications to the CH-53E - 152 and MH-53E - 29 aircraft.  The aircraft inventories to be modified vary by Operational, Safety, and Improvement Program, dependant on kit modification production lead-time.  The CH-53E is a seven blade main rotor and a four-blade canted tail rotor helicopter powered by three T64-GE-416/416A/419 turbo shaft engines while the CH-53D has six main rotor blades and two T64-GE-413/416 engines.  Per United States Marine Corps Aviation Plan, the CH-53D series retired Dec 2012.  The CH-53D/E aircraft are capable of both land and ship based transport of heavy equipment, supplies, and personnel.  The MH-53E is similar to the CH-53E with additional capabilities for Airborne Mine Countermeasures, Vertical On-Board Delivery, and Special Missions which require longer range and more precise navigation than that of the CH-53E.  The overall goal of the modifications budgeted in FY14 is increased communication and navigation, integrated mechanical diagnostics, propulsion and power, degraded visual environment mitigation, survivability and sustainment initiatives, night vision capability, and fleet operation and safety performance in the H-53 community.

The H-53E number 1 & number 3 engine Nacelles are a safety risk due to Things Falling Off Aircraft (TFOA). To date (81) TFOA occurences have occured (12 in the last 3 years) on the H-53E aircraft.  Of the (81) occurences, (10) have impacted the Tail Rotor.  The H-53E Engine Nacelles have become a top Direct Maintenance Man Hour driver in the fleet. This procurement would improve fleet safety and readiness.  H-53 Avionics (31-12).  H-53 Smart Multi Function Color Display (SMFCD).  This request will provide procurement and installation for forward deployed aircraft with Integrated form, fit solution for display of Blue Force Tracker, Forward Looking Infrared with intuitive hover display, and real time threat display for aircraft Survival Equipment suite in a SMFCD.

Name.@footnote: Q-29A-OCO - The previous quantity of 4 was an error.

Description.val:
The Helicopter Night Vision System (HNVS) will provide an infrared night vision system for the CH-53E transport helicopters.  The HNVS provides an improved night/all weather mission capability.  This Operational, Safety, and Improvement Program includes integration of the off the shelf APN-217(V)6 Doppler Navigation System and AAQ-29A Forward Looking Infrared (FLIR).  Future configuration for CH-53E transport helicopter will be the AAQ-29A FLIR due to obsolescence issues for original equipment manufacturer with AAQ-16B.  Program is structured to replace AAQ-16 with AAQ-29A to establish a single configuration.

DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES:    The AAQ-16B/29 FLIR is a non-developmental Item currently installed on a number of United States Army, Air Force, and Navy helicopters.  Development Test-IIIA on the CH-53E/HNVS was completed in the third quarter FY 94.  Extension of application for CH-53E was granted first quarter FY 95.  The AAQ-29A is currently in production.

ImplementationMethodName.val: Not Installed - MH-53E Cruise Box Kits

Description.val:
Utility and Troop transport mission increasing in importance.  Current troop/passenger seats are 1950 generation.  Design does not provide impact protection of current rotorcraft seat designs.  The impulsive type loading experienced during survivable mishaps produces amplified seat/floor anchor loads and potentially injurious occupant decelerations.  Due to this operational deficiency, NDI crashworthy troop seat program established.  Non-Developmental Item are lightweight off-the-shelf seats that provide protection by limiting an occupants inertial loading to survivable levels by attenuating impact forces to below survivable ranges and enables the occupant to rapidly egress a downed aircraft are being sought. 

DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES:  Funding provided non-recurring engineering, qualification, initial procurement, support and installs for Crash Attenuating Crew Chief Seat (CACCS) for all H-53 Type/Model/Series helicopters. CACCS also requires a redesigned Cruise box for the MH-53E.

Notes:
1.  Crash Attenuating Troop Seat (CATSS) Upgrade kits [quantity (QTY) 246] are installed at O-level.  QTY (7) kits previously reflected in FY12 buy were procured prior year. 
2.  CACCS was incorrectly listed as B kit and has been updated to reflect A kit procurement and install schedule.  Install dollars required in FY12 and FY13.  Due to early sundown of CH-53D, QTY (22) CACCS installs will not be completed.
3.  MH-53E CATSS Kits correctly reflects prior year procurement of (5) vice (4).

Integrated Mechanical Diagnostics (IMD) is a helicopter monitoring and diagnostics system that provides continuous on board monitoring and diagnostics of engine health, gearbox and drive train vibrations, oil debris, rotor track and balance. Full incorporation of the IMD system capabilities will allow rapid transition from the current costly philosophies of the 70s to today's cost wise initiatives and concepts. Lessons learned from this effort were incorporated into the solicitation for the fleet wide IMD effort with CH/MH-53E aircraft designated as the lead platforms.  IMD produces the aircraft interface required to implement military flight operations quality assurance, a capability designed to provide hazard monitoring and mitigation.  Condition Based Maintenance (CBM) is a concept intended to direct maintenance by predicting failures based on real-time assessment of equipment condition obtained from Integrated Mechanical Diagnostics System (IMDS) embedded sensors.  CBM program includes software algorithm analysis for condition and health indicators of components,  implementation of diagnostic/analysis tools and information infrastructure.  CBM will enable a reduction in spares and maintenance while increasing safety of flight.

DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES:   The CH-53E IMDS successfully completed operational evaluation in October 2005.  The Milestone Decision Authority approved full-rate production for CH-53E IMDS in December 2004. MH-53E Validation completed 1st Qtr FY11.  The MH-53E Verification was completed 1st Qtr FY13.  Advanced diagnostics enhancements and airframe structural life extension database interfaces are being incorporated to provide comprehensive platform operational and maintenance status awareness to the Squadron Commanders and key decision makers.

Notes:
1.  QTY of 154 CH-53E installs includes 2 trainer kits.
2.  QTY of 31 MH-53E installs includes 1 trainer kit (FY13) and 2 spares (result of 2 mishaps).
3.  Lack of MH-53E aircraft availability delaying installations of FY12 kit buy.
4.  Lack of CH-53E aircraft availability delaying installations of prior year kit buy.
5.  IMDS FY15-FY18 support costs are for IMDS configuration changes to provide continued system internet authority. CBM data will drive software changes for aging aircraft components.  
6.  Increase in Support Equipment for FY13 reflects additional test sets to improve readiness, reduce maintenance costs/time to repair the aircraft.

Material quality defects were discovered in the first production lot.  Technical data package was studied by the Original Equipment Manufacturer.  Contract awarded February 07 for Non-Recurring Engineering, tooling and validation/verification kits. 

DESCRIPTION/JUSTIFICATION:  The CH/MH-53E No.1 & No. 3 engine Nacelles are a safety risk due to Things Falling Off Aircraft (TFOA). TFOA incidents risk damage to the aircraft, threaten aircrew safety, and could potentially impact personnel and/or property on the ground.  The H-53E Engine Nacelles have become a Direct Maintenance Man Hour (MMH) driver in the fleet. The procurement improves fleet safety and readiness.  The new CH/MH-53E Nacelle ship sets incorporate improved material properties, design, and positive locking latching mechanisms to prevent TFOA.  Improved Nacelles will ensure the highest readiness levels.  

The H-53E No.1 & No. 3 engine Nacelles are a safety risk due to TFOA. To date 81 TFOA occurences have occured (12 in the last 3 years) on the H-53E aircraft.  Of the 81 occurences, 10 have impacted the Tail Rotor.  The CH/MH-53E Engine Nacelles have become a top MMH driver in the fleet. This procurement would improve fleet safety and readiness.

DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR MILESTONES:  This modification provides improvements to the engine nacelles which are intended to decrease the maintenance man-hours expended on nacelles repair and replacement.  This modification will incorporate the forward and aft engine nacelles for the H-53.

Notes:
1.  All installations are O-level.
2.  QTY of 154 CH-53E installs includes 2 trainer kits.


Current Active Modifications:
MH-53 E KITS (Radian)- Improved MH-53 GKN Nacelles which incorporate design changes to improve reliability/rigidity, risk analysis, metal numerical control (n/c) tooling, fabrication of two ship sets and teardown/inspection/test of Nacelles for No. 1 and No.3 engines. O level install.

Future Modifications:
MH-53 Kit - Organic - O level install for improved GKN Nacelles to incorporate design changes to improve reliability/rigidity, risk analysis, metal numerical control (n/c) tooling, fabrication of two ship sets and teardown/inspection/test of Nacelles for No. 1 and No.3 engines.
CH-53 Kits - Organic - O level install for Improved GKN Nacelles kits.

Archived Modifications:
CH-53E Kits Validation/Verification - O level install for Improved GKN Nacelles kits.

Operational Commitments have kept Aircraft from inducting on time delaying installs funded with Overseas Operation Contingency (OCO) funds.

The T64 Engine Reliability Improvement Program (ERIP) upgrades top age related engine degraders, fatigue limiters, and performance degradation on the T64 engine. A concentrated effort is to upgrade the T64-416 engines to the T64-416A configuration by replacing components of the engine with improved hardware designs to increase reliability and reduce logistical requirements by conforming to one configuration. T64 engines will be modified to incorporate titanium nitride-coated compressor airfoils.  Titanium nitride coating provides significantly improved durability and reliability for operation in austere environments.  Degraded and obsolete peculiar support equipment will also be improved.

DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES: 358 of 460 engines have been upgraded from the T64-416 to T64-416A configuration. T64-416A upgrade kits procured with FY04 Title IX Supplemental funding began installs in FY05. T64-416 and -416A engines began incorporating titanium nitride in FY04.  T64-419 engines began incorporating titanium nitride in FY06.  T64-413 engines began incorporating titanium nitride in FY07, and were completed in FY11 when the FY11 United States Marine Corps Aviation Plan was released.

Notes:
1.  All ERIP procurements are for mods catagorized as B-kits.  Contract award for FY12 quantities is anticipated February 2013.  
2.  Non-recurring installation cost identifies funding for T64 ERIP mods to be installed/implemented by Fleet Readiness Center (FRC) artisans.  This cost consists of labor and consumable materials necessary to implement the various Accessory Changes and Powerplant Changes that make up the T64 ERIP.  Fiscal Year quantities are based on FRC shop throughput, appropriate kit availability, and anticipated retrograde component availability.

Description.val:
This funding effort is established for procurement and integration of survivability systems that will improve H-53 aircrew and passengers against hostile threats through more effective self-defense methods. The H-53 survivability strategy is to upgrade threat detection ability, increase countermeasure capability, reduce vulnerability, enhance situational awareness by communicating aircraft position to deconflict with friendly forces in the area of operation, and improve vulnerability to battle damage by better developing protection for both the aircrew and critical components.  This increased survivability will protect the H-53 during all aspects of its various missions; assault support, shipboard delivery of cargo, anti-mine warfare, casualty transport/Medivac, and heavy cargo transport.

H-53 Smart Multi Function Color Display (SMFCD). SMFCD moving to Avionics OSIP 31-12 as of FY14.  Current Marine Air Ground Task Force (MAGTF)future force laydown plans shows Air Combat Element (ACE) MAGTF elements will not change in Operation Enduring Freedom OEF through FY14.  A MAGTF ACE will remain deployed in OEF in order to support Special Operating Forces beyond FY14 (current plans through FY16).  SMFCD improves aircrew safety by reducing pilot workload and fatigue and increases aircrew situational awareness.  SMFCD provides an integrated avionics suite that will facilitate safe landings in a degraded visual environment, modernize navigational equipment and enhance situational awareness with a joint single integrated air ground picture.  SMFCD provides the capability of displaying a Brown Out Symbology Set on the instrument panel in the pilot's normal field of view, allowing aircrews to land in dusty environments, and reducing the risk of Controlled Flight Into Terrain (CFIT) that results in loss of life and aircraft. 7 CH-53 CFIT MISHAPS FY05-FY12 (2 OIF/5 OEF) resulted in the loss of 3 aircraft and 32 people killed in action.  SMFCD provides a real time threat display for the Aircraft Survivability Equipment threat indications currently encountered, such as missiles, small arms, and lasers, overlaid on a real time moving map in the pilot's normal field of view, vice several federated systems scattered around the cockpit.  SMFCD further increases safety by eliminating the kneeboard Electronic Display Module (EDM) which currently tethers the pilot to the aircraft, creating an egress hazard during emergency situations.  Additionally, SMFCD is a form fit replacement for the current Forward Looking Infrared (FLIR) display and retains the full FLIR functionality.  All Overseas Contingency Operations (OCO) systems will be procured and installed prior to end of FY14.

DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES:  Aircraft Survivability Equipment effort (18 aircraft) completed  August 2008.  Blue Force Tracker (BFT) fully equipped aircraft deployment completed June 2008.  BFT is an Army Acquisition Category IC program, encryption and L-band enhancements are anticipated.

Notes:	
1.  Installation of QTY (152) Visually Degraded Environment (VDE) A-kits procured in VDE OSIP 20-07 with FY10 OCO are occurring simultaneously with BFT installs.  Of the (152) installs, QTY (20) will occur in FY13 with OCO funding in Survivability OSIP 15-05.  Remaining installs will be completed in FY13 QTY (40), with OCO funding in Avionics OSIP 31-12.  
2.  Critical Systems Upgrade (CSU) is comprised of BFT kits, Satellite Communicatons (SATCOM) 1851A radios, advanced digital antenna production, Heads Up Display (HUD) software, controlled display navigation unit and software upgrades in support of the VDE solution.
3.  Lack of CH-53E aircraft availability is delaying installation of BFT prior year kit buy.
4.  Lack of CH-53E aircraft availability is delaying installation of FY 12 CSA.
5.  SMFCD total kit QTY is (160).  QTY (152) aircraft installs and (8) trainers.  QTY (67) will be procured in Survivability OSIP 15-05.  QTY of (5) SMFCD (3 production kits, 1 validation kit, 1 verification kit) procured with FY10 supplemental (Supp)(via Above Threshold Reprogramming October 10) are installed in FY12.  QTY of (25) kit and install funding was released for execution based on the Omnibus 2011 II prior approval reprogramming action (FY11-25 PA) on 11-7-11 as part of United States Marine Corps Helicopter Survivability Task Force initiative (FY11 General Fund).  QTY (37) kits will be procured and installed with FY12 OCO.  The remaining QTY (93) SMFCD will be procured (to complete) in Avionics OSIP (31-12).		
6.  Critical Systems Armor (CSA) A-kit procurement and installs were reflected incorrectly on prior budgets and has been updated.  FY12 OCO will fund QTY (43) CSA installs in FY13. 
7.  Operational commitment has kept Aircraft from inducting on time, delaying installation.

BFT incorporates Force Battle Command Brigade and Below (FBCB2) capability in the H-53; provides near real-time tracking and displaying of friendly forces in the cockpit and increased situational awareness.  2 EDMs, and existing Global Positioning System are utilized, provides over-the-Horizon coverage with L-band Commercial SATCOM and 2-way data and Variable Message Format(VMF) messaging overlay on EDM moving map.

SMFCD A Kits - SMFCD will increase aircrew situational awareness and reduce pilot workload/fatigue by consolidating the threat warning, BFT, FLIR, hover symbology, and moving map on one easily seen "under-glass" multi-function programmable display. Integrating all this data decreases the chances for CFIT and increases situational awareness while hovering under degraded visibility conditions such as snow, sand or, dust.

Description.val:
The H-53 Aircraft are included in the Headquarters Marine Corps Aviation Plan through Calendar Year 2025. The H-53 Aircraft Sustainment Strategy targets initiatives to remedy the top age-related maintenance degraders,  fatigue life limiters, and safety issues that impede the aircraft's ability to operate into the future. This program implements a concentrated effort to utilize improvements to the H-53 component obsolescence (e.g. Engine Air Particle Separator (EAPS) redesign), structural limitations (e.g. transition bulkhead and station 820 structural improvement), aircrew safety systems and program sustainment support. This effort will sustain the H-53 legacy fleet in an affordable manner until the H-53 follow-on aircraft becomes available.

DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES:    The H-53 Sustainment Program Acquisition Strategy was approved by Program Executive Office(Aircraft) in March 2006, to be executed as four Abbreviated Acquisition Programs (AAPs) for (1) Fatigue, (2) Obsolescence, (3) Readiness, and (4) Safety.  Each AAP consists of several independent projects, each of which has an independent platform effectivity, acquisition strategy, production lead time, production rate and quantity, and installation approach.  Thus, they are not amenable to a "block upgrade" type approach.  Each year of the program will involve non-recurring engineering (NRE) on some projects, leading to production and installation in out-years.  Other projects require little or no NRE and can be acquired and installed quickly during maintenance.  

Notes:
1.  EAPS A Kits are QTY (3) per aircraft; Engineering Change Proposal 6503 increased EAPS total qty from 513 to 642; EAPS prior year QTY (366) kits with Overseas Contingency Operations (OCO) funds are installed starting in FY12.
2.  EAPS Improvement delay in install is due to Aircraft Availability.
3.  Arc Fault Circuit Breaker (AFCB)- Prior Year QTY (433) represented individual circuit cards, Prior year QTY changed to (161) to represent aircraft total kit quantities.  AFCB is a Comercial Off The Shelf item and there is no associated contract/delivery data.
4.  Common Generator Control Unit project was canceled, will procure Improved Generator Control Unit as B kit.
5.  CH-53E EAPS Seal QTY (65) was procured as A Kit but not installed due to cancellation of effort. 
6.  Install schedule for #2 Engine Backflow incorrectly reflected prior year installs-kits were procured with FY10 OCO funding but installs have been delayed due to technical issues with the design.
7.  Install schedules for Aircrew Cooling, and Kapton incorrectly reflected prior year quantities, and have been updated.  
8.  AFCB install schedule has been added. Long Lead time for adminstration of contract.  Delivery delayed due to production time and MH/CH-53E aircraft availabily.  
9.  Helicopter Emergency Egress Lighting System was incorrectly shown as a B Kit procurement and has been moved to an A Kit procurement with an install schedule shown. 
10.  FY12 is the last year for Transition Bulkhead installs.
11.  EAPS, Kapton and Aircrew Cooling installs are funded with prior year OCO funds.
12.  AFCB Installs on hold due to pending engineering investigation.

Current Active Modifications:
Engine Backflow (CH/MH-E)-NonOrganic - Installation of a new ram-air duct onto the #2 engine cowling to improve airflow through the engine compartment to mitigate a top H-53 safety risk of hot engine exhaust back-flowing through the compartment that has led to in-flight fires and loss of aircraft.
Aircrew Cooling-NonOrganic - installation of mini cooling units in the H-53E cabin to mitigate heat stress for aircrew.
Arc Fault Circuit Breaker (AFCB)-NonOrganic - replaces legacy thermal circuit breakers with modernized solid-state electronic circuit breakers able to react in a timely manner to a wiring fault, reducing potential of electrical arcing and inflight fires.
CH-53 Engine Air Particle Separator (EAPS) Kits - integration hardware, subsystem modificaitons, and system components necessary to install the EAPS Bypass replacement kits to the H-53 aircraft structure.
CH-53 EAPS Bypass - kit improvements to greatly reduce/eliminate current issues between EAPS barrell and engine decreasing erosion to blades and vanes, increasing power margins, decreasing unscheduled engine maintenance or removals and increasing availability.
EAPS Improv Kits
H-53 Helicopter Emergency Egress Lighting System (HEELS) - installation of a self-contained, fiber formed electro-luminescent technology that lights escape paths for crew/passengers to maintain orientation in the event of a mishap.
Kapton Wiring Kits - Replaces deficient legacy wiring throughout the H-53E cabin. Now known to rapidly degrade with age, particularly in the maritime environment that naval aircraft operate and have been cited as teh causal factor of over 100 documented incidences of electric malfunction and fire.
Obsolescent Components - installation of upgrades/replacements to various obsolete legacy components.
Transition Bulkhead (CH/MH-E)-NonOrganic - removes and replaces fatigue life limited airframe structural component.

Operational Commitments have kept Aircraft from inducting on time delaying installs funded with Overseas Operation Contingency (OCO) funds.

Visually Degraded Environment (VDE) is the greatest unmitigated challenge faced by Marine Aviation in its current operating environment.  The loss of visual ground reference during night landings to unimproved, dusty landing zones is the greatest safety risk to H-53 aircrew, passengers and aircraft. The H-53 will continue to operate in VDE and continue to endanger flight crews and passengers while flying in a low altitude/low airspeed regime or landing in unimproved landing zones in conditions that may cause loss of a visual reference due to dust, snow, fog, smoke or darkness.  A VDE solution will facilitate mission accomplishment in all degraded cueing environments, prevent degraded cueing environment mishaps and subsequent loss of life and assets.  Reference: CH-53 Zero Visibility Landing System Urgent Need Statement # 06069UB, approved 27 February 06.

Phase I VDE solution was incorporated as part of the Critical Survivability Upgrade (CSU) procuring software development, equipment and data rights for the incorporation of VDE in the Heads Up Display (HUD).  Additionally, SATCOM 1851A radios, Radio Controlled Unit (RCU's), Radio Transmitter (RT's) antennas, mounts, wiring kits and navigational faceplates are procured as part of the solution.

DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES:  Program Management Air Office 261 is currently supporting technology development, demonstration, and integration in a phased approach to the VDE solution.  Prototype installation of a system providing enhanced cuing to the flying pilot is underway.  Technology development and demonstration of laser and Radio Frequency based systems are underway with flight test of a laser-based system, as installed on an H-53 September, 2009.  Cancellation of the Communication Navigation Surveillance/Air Traffic Management (CNS/ATM) program for the CH-53E in FY10 resulted in a restructuring of the approach to providing pilots with advanced cuing in VDE. This was accomplished by integration with the previously installed Embedded Global Positioning System and Inertial navigation system and Head's Up Display.  Installs of this solution were performed incidentally with other avionics changes beginning in FY11.  

Notes:
1.  Installation of QTY (152) VDE A-kits [procured in VDE OSIP 20-07 with FY10 Overseas Contingency Operations (OCO)] are occurring simultaneously with Blue Force Tracker installs.  Of the (152) installs, QTY (20) will occur in FY12 with OCO funding in Survivability Operational, Safety, and Improvement Program (OSIP) 15-05.  Remaining installs QTY (40)will be completed with OCO funding in Avionics OSIP 31-12.  
2.  Operational commitment has kept Aircraft from inducting on time, delaying installation.

Operational Commitments have kept Aircraft from inducting on time delaying installs funded with Overseas Operation Contingency (OCO) funds.

Description.val:
Currently, the H-53 has only Infrared (IR) detection equipment and rudimentary flares for use as countermeasure.  This funding is for Engineering Change Proposal (ECP) development, A-kit procurement and installation of a Direct Infrared Counter Measure (DIRCM) system for H-53s.  This system will help protect the H-53 which is highly susceptible to IR seeking manpads, the weapon of choice in all current theaters.  This system has been found effective against fourth generation IR manpads, and is extremely effective earlier generation manpads. 

DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES:  Non-Recurring engineering (NRE) for the CH-53E began in May 07 and concluded with a completed and verified Technical Directive (TD) in early FY09.  Test and Evaluation for the CH-53E began with risk-reduction testing in April 08 and concluded with Inital Operational Test and Evaluation (IOT&E)in late FY09.  Critical to early fielding was the Quick reaction assessment, completed in August 08 which lead to an Early Operational Capability (EOC) decision in November 08. Validation and verification were conducted for the CH-53E between May - September 08.  Non-Recurring engineering for the CH-53D began in May 08 and concluded with a completed and verified TD in early FY10.  The FY11 United States Marine Corps Aviation Plan was released in October 2010 and called for the early retirement of the CH-53D.  Development and deployment of the DIRCM system on the CH-53D system was subsequently suspended and remaining funding realigned to other priorities consistent with Headquarters Marine Corps direction.  DIRCM is being procured as a mission kit by PMA-272.  All CH-53Ds & CH-53Es must be modified with an A-kit to accept the mission kit.  Installations surged in FY09 to achieve an EOC and then continue through FY14.  



Notes:
1.  Total QTY (156) reflects 152 CH-53E kits, (1) maintenance trainer and (3) CH-53D kits (prototype validation/verification).
2.  FY11 CH-53 (DIRCM Rev-A) A kits QTY (153) are a revision to an existing kit.  QTY (46) are already planned for install with DIRCM baseline kits at no additional cost FY12 and FY13.  DIRCM "re-touch" installs will occur FY13-15 QTY (107).

Description.val:
This Operational, Safety and Improvement Program (OSIP) will fund avionics systems for the H-53 helicopter. The H-53 strategy is to address safety, survivability, system obsolescence, and avionics deficiencies that require correction to maintain platform relevance on an increasingly networked battlefield.  Specifically, this OSIP addresses Critical Survivability Upgrade (CSU) installations. CSU leverages the aircraft state, rate, and acceleration data available through integration of the H764G Embedded Global Positioning System/Inertial Navigation System and development of improved hover symbology in providing the Phase I Degraded Visual Environment (DVE) solution. The CSU program also provides the platform for the installation of the APX-123 Transponder meeting Mode 5 Inital Operational Capability requirements.  Targeted improvements include, but are not limited to Aircraft Survival Equipment (ASE) upgrades, lack of 8.33 kHz frequency separation Fleet Requirements Document compliance, Area Navigation (RNAV) and Required Navigation Performance (RNP) (RNP/RNAV) certification, Variable Message Format Revision D change 1 compliance, embedded Terrain Avoidance and Warning System (eTAWS) integration, Collision Avoidance System integration, Over-the-Horizon communications and Crash Survivable Flight Data Recorder. Safety related improvements include lack of a solution mitigating Controlled Flight Into Terrain risk when operating in DVE.  Blue Force Tracker (BFT) kneeboard hazard is corrected with the incorporation of an integrated Multi-Function Display (MFD) capable of processing and displaying a variety of flight and situational awareness information to pilots. Additionally, this funding provides or the integration of cockpit avionics with ASE to provide time critical data to other battlefield users in order to more rapidly prosecute threats. This funding effort seeks to eliminate these, and other, avionics and ASE related system level deficiencies and safety hazards with the above described improvements as well as ensuring that all H-53 aircraft are equipped with a full complement of ASE required to operate on the modern networked battlefield.

Smart Multi Function Color Display (SMFCD) improves aircrew safety by reducing pilot workload and fatigue and increases aircrew situational awareness.  SMFCD provides an integrated avionics suite that will facilitate safe landings in a degraded visual environment, modernize navigational equipment and enhance situational awareness with a joint single integrated air ground picture.  SMFCD provides the capability of displaying a Brown Out Symbology Set (BOSS)on the instrument panel in the pilot's normal field of fiew, allowing aircrews to land in dusty environments, and reducing the risk of Controlled Flight Into Terrain (CFIT) that results in loss of life and aircraft.  7 CH-53 CFIT MISHAPS FY-5-FY12 (2 OIF/5 OEF)resulted in the loss of 3 aircraft and 32 people killed in action.  SMFCD provides a real time threat display for the Aircraft Survivability Equipment threat indications currently encountered, such as missiles, small arms, and lasers, overlaid on a real time moving map in the pilot's normal field of view, vice several federated systems scattered around the cockpit.  SMFCD further increases safety by elimnating the kneeboard Electronic Display Module (EDM) which currently tethers the pilot to the aircraft, creating an egress hazard during emergency situations.  Additionally, SMFCD is a form fit replacement forthe current Forward Looking Infrared (FLIR) display and retains the full FLIR functionality.  All Overseas Contingency Operations (OCO) systems will be procured and installed prior to end of FY14.

H-53 Smart Multi Function Color Display (SMFCD) moving to Avionics OSIP 31-12 as of FY14.  Current Marine Air Ground Task Force (MAGTF) future force laydown plans shows Air Combat Element (ACE) MAGTF elements will not change in Operation Enduring Freedom (OEF) through FY14.  A MAGTF ACE will remain deployed in OEF in order to support Special Operating Forces beyond FY14 (current plans through FY16).  Current MAGTF future force laydown plans shows ACE MAGTF elements will not change in OEF through FY14. 

DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES: NRE efforts for modification of eTAWS algorithm for the H-53 aircraft will be completed June 13. Production and installation effort of eTAWS capable MFD will complete in September 15.

Notes:
1.  Installation of QTY (152) Visual Degraded Environment (VDE) A-kits [procured in VDE OSIP 20-07 with FY10 Overseas Contingency Operations (OCO)] are occurring simultaneously with BFT installs.  Of the (152) installs, QTY (92) occured prior year, QTY (20) will occur in FY12 with OCO funding in Survivability OSIP 15-05.  Remaining installs will be completed in FY13 QTY (40), with OCO funding in Avionics OSIP 31-12.  (QTY (40) BFT kit shown in A-Kit procurement at zero dollars in this OSIP).
2.  Smart Multi-Function Color Display (SMFCD) total kit QTY is 160.  QTY (152) aircraft installs and (8) trainers.  
QTY (67) in Survivability OSIP 15-05 and QTY (93) in Avionics OSIP 31-12.
